Name: Physics of the Impossible: A Scientific Exploration into the World of Phasers, Force Fields, Teleportation, and Time Travel

ReviewList.Text: This is probably Dr. Kaku's best popular work since Hyperspace or Visions.  Here is a wide range of scientific possibilities to be explored.  Dr. Kaku's gift is to make modern physics comprehensible to those of us without a mathematical background.  In this book he uses his gift to explain how the standard model and string field theory (which he is coauthor of) can be applied to contemplation of some of our most wildest scifi dreams.  The chapters are short and easily read in short sittings, which lends well to a book that stretches the imagination so dramaticaly.  Dr. Kaku is also careful to remain objective in discussing different theoretical approaches which is an admirable feat given some of the topics ventured into in this book.  If you enjoy cutting edge science, it doesn't get more cutting edge then this.  Thank you Dr. Kaku for yet another wonderful journey.

Very good book for inquiring minds.  Dr. Kaku is a genius and does a great job of making this book easy enough to understand but not too simplistic.  Nice balance for those who have a curiosity about such things but not a background in physics.

Kaku presents the daunting advanced concepts of physics to readers in an enjoyable journey through the possibilities of force fields, ray guns, Star Wars force abilities (through psychokinesis), time travel, and much more.  The greatest strength of this book is the presentation of recent breakthroughs such as the seemingly invisible "metamaterials" that disappear under a specific frequency of light, or the series of breakthroughs that can be achieved with the possible discovery of room-temperature superconductors.  Kaku is an appealing master storyteller (as seen in his appearances on The Universe series on the History Channel) and Physics of the Impossible is a wonderful book offering much food for thought.

Michio Kaku is a well-respected theoretical physicist and astronomer, who can lucidly explain some of the universe's most complex concepts.  He agains fails to disappoint in "Physics of the Impossible," an incredibly interesting analysis documenting how many theories have passed from the realm of science fiction into science fact.  This is a must-read for astronomy enthusiasts like myself. 5 stars!!!

Michio Kaku carries persons, without a keen knowledge of physics into the real problems that have been solved and that probably will be solved in that realm of science.  He has the ability to communicate down to the lowest level and tell me the reader just what Stephen Hawking is thinking and how it just may be possible.

A neat, easily understandable breakdown of the physics behind some of the inventions and innovations that feature prominently in science fiction stories including time travel, lightspeed engines and parallel universes. Good for readers with an interest in science, but a deep background isn't necessary to follow any of the explanations.

michio kaku has again brought his knowledge and excitement about science to a broader readership. in this book michio takes us through scientific research and speculation on scientific issues and questions of our times...and for many generations to come. a stimulating, exciting, challenging read...michio,thank you once again.

I must admit to being surprised at how well  Professor Kaku wrote this book in a way that even a high school student would be able to comprehend. I recomemd this book to anyone that has an intrest in science, not just physics! i can say one thing for sure: I will be buying more of his books in the future.

This is the first book that I have read by Michio Kaku and I am now a fan.  I enjoyed the book and the way that the author explains things by linking them through science fiction. There were a few chapters where I expected more information or more detail.  Overall an entertaining read.

Author.Name: Donald Mitchell
Author.Location: Thanks for Providing My Reviews over 127,000 Helpful Votes Globally

ReviewList.Text: I found this book to be not only an exploration of the fringes of science, but also a discussion of some of the subtleties of quantum theory from the point of view of a "string theorist";quite interesting.

I love books written for non-mathematicians about subjects like string theory, black holes, higher math, cosmology in general.  So naturally I was attracted to this book.  The author divides his topics into "nearly possible today", "possible in the remote future" and "nearly impossible", or something like that.  I found his explanations of why phenomena like teleportation,  sophisticated robots, force fields to power rockets, etc. might be possible "soon" were not very clear explanations. At the other end of the book,  I think he should have dismissed ideas such as building a "death star" that costs 400 quadrillion dollars, or travel to distant galaxies with devices that require harnessing the energy of entire galaxies to do so, as mere fantasies rather than elevating them to the level of something worthy of substantive discussion.  In short, the author glibly crosses from science to science fiction without identifying some of the ideas as the latter -- he appears to do so just because popular books or movies were about some of them.
Non technical treatment of physics concepts as they relate to science fiction themes. Michio Kaku is an engaging writer who can discuss the science authoritatively with our boring you.
The book is easy reading for a person not heavily involved with science. It is informative and makes you want to think about events and discoveries yet to come.

BookTV is showing an InDepth interview of Michio Kaku done October 3, 1010. This is my first exposure to him and to his ideas and naturally, I am in awe; grateful too for his easy ability to bridge his world of physics to this little layperson. I immediately came here to order at least one of his books, and find out more about Dr. Kaku and his books written for the general public. I want to thank Amazon and the reviewers here for having the rating bar graph and forum for input. All is thoughtfully done, and helpful...thank you. So, my review is more a comment with gratitude attached for this review process available. To mention, if you can make the time, this InDepth interview gives three and a half hours, (booktv.org), of this amazing author and theoretical physicist talking about science in quite an engaging, personable way.

Physics of the impossible explores common themes in science fiction, and explains in simplified physics whether such things are possible soon, or far in the future. Kaku has an engaging writing style, and his physics is basic enough that most popular readers would be able to follow. However, I don't think people who follow physics regularly would enjoy the simplified science. I enjoyed this book, though I have one major complaint: Kaku would give examples of science fiction phenomena from popular novels. Apparently assuming that everyone has read all of these books, he almost always tells the ending of the book. I hadn't read several of these books and was quite annoyed since telling the end of the book did not add any merit to his own arguments. The book lost star-points because of this problem.

Physics of the Impossible is my first Michio Kaku book, and even though I haven't quite finished it yet, I can certainly tell you that I will be buying another, and probably one after that.  Kaku's writings are styled in a way that appeals to a general audience interested on the general topic of scientific fantasy and reality.  I try to read half a chapter to a chapter every day, and every day my mind is blown by what is in this book.  Part of me wants to be done with this book so that I can read Kaku's other books, while the other part wants this book to never end.  Looking forward to his other works!

I've read a whole lot of books on modern physics, but very few held my interest like this one. Not only is it concise and easy to read, it's also a lot of fun to see how science fiction may one day become science. It gives you a lot to think about and really inspires awe: some of the things he talks about are not too far off, but some of them seem impossibly elusive. But overall, if you love science fiction and are interested in how those concepts in scifi would work in the real world (e.g., teleportation, telepathy, force fields, etc), then this book is definitely for you.

This was a stellar book. (ha ha.) It takes very complex physics issues and relates them to technologies we are all familiar with, at least if we've ever seen Star Trek, Star Wars, Battlestar Galactica, etc. For everyone with an imagination about how the world might be some day, this book is for you. It is filled with easy to understand, down to earth examples of how and why these technologies might work, or might not work. As a complete physics layman, I enjoyed this book thoroughly, and somewhat regret not studying harder in college.

Being a big fan of the Discovery, Science, and Nat Geo channels I find myself frequently overwhelmed with current theories and discoveries. 'They said this, yet he said that'. Dr. Kaku brushes back our errant hairs of confusion and clearly does a "Cliffs Notes" of almost everything around us. The universe and the multi-verse make sense, and allows us to stretch out and knead our brain cells like those weird grey rubber erasers you used in art class. The results were unexpected yet transient. You saw it for a moment moving into something else. Dr. Kaku seizes on these moments and glides us effortlessly into a whole new set of dimensions that further support the ideas of a great number of intellectuals that risked everything to lead the way in the multi-verse that we live in.

Dr. Kaku does a great job of going through all the sci fi impossible physics and breaks it all down for us. He's very smart but is able to communicate well with the un-scienced majority. Every now and then he goes into evolution-speak of telling us that we all come from mud, but many scientist spout the same thing. I wouldn't call the book a grand slam but it's definitely an infield home run. You'll like it and it will expand your view of what is possible and what is truly impossible.

I first saw an interview with Michio Kaku on the Science Channel and was immediately interested in him and his ideas.  When the cover caught my eye in the bookstore I just had to read it.  Michio clearly and simply lays out a number of theories or inventions that have been deemed impossible and breaks them down into their physical laws and then categorizes them on their actually possibility.  A must read for anyone interested in theoretical physics.

I'm still in the process of reading this book but what I've read so far is very intersting.  I enjoy the references to Star Trek and the humor that keeps everything from getting too technical.  The writing style is easy to understand and leaves you with a feeling of awe at the possibilities available to science both now and in the future.  A good read for those interested in such things.

I like Michio Kaku's writing style personally.  I think he does a good job of explaining physics to the lay person.  In this book in particular, his discussion of popular science fiction topics, related to current physics knowledge is fun to read.  I can't say how accurate his predictions are or judge his applied sciences but the concepts are nice to ponder.

Mr. Kaku explores what might be possible decades or millennia from today and rules out those sci-fi ideas that are totally against the laws of physics.  Not of much practical use, but interesting.  It does help the layman who has an interest in the frontiers of physics to sort out the wheat from the chaff in science and science fiction writings.

This book is just plain FUN!  It became the basis for the popular "Sci-Fi Science" TV show and is filled with Dr. Kaku's trademark humor and excitement. If you're interested in science, don't miss it. If you're not interested in science, read it anyway -- you'll find it quite accessible, and you might find out that science is fun after all.

Great read about sci-fi stuff and how it can become reality. I like that it's easy language to understand, with no math or physics equations at all. Plus he incorporates history and pop culture into his writing so that's great! He discusses: teleportation, time travel, telepathy, force fields and lots more.

This is my favorite physics popularization book.  The conclusions seem correct on all the major subjects, and I can feel the advantage of having an accomplished physicist doing the explaining.  Kaku does a good job of maintaining logical consistency and structure while avoiding the math technicals.

LIke all of Dr. Kaku's books, this volume pushes the envelope of oiur current scientific understanding. This is where reality meets science fiction of the believable variety. And is written in a manner that does not require advanced degrees in physics. A must for the adventurous of mind.

I've read quiet a few of kakus works and enjoy them immensely. My only problem is that these works often site ideas without actually explaining what they are in depth besides giving the name. This would inevitably make for a much longer book but would be well worth it in my opinion.

This book is a good book for people who are not very versed in physics. There are only a few parts where it starts to drift into that realm that makes no sense to lay people. If you are a physics student, you will find it somewhat elementary. Overall a good read.

Author.Name: Fred Forbes
Author.Location: Financial Planner in Palmetto, FL USA

ReviewList.Text: I give this book to all my new companions when they start flying around with me in my Type 40 TARDIS. It helps them grasp a better understanding of just how much running they will be doing. I remember when I took on Michio Kaku as a companion just before he began writing this book. We traveled to the Sigma cluster of the Medusa Cascade, and held conferences with the Ood brain and discussed the philosophical concepts behind the ethics of interfering with historical events on Earth. Kaku proved himself when he made a counter thesis to the theorized negative consequences that the Ood proposed to me. We then traveled to the American Civil War where Kaku helped Abraham Lincoln construct the first Mini-Gun to be used in the battle of Bull's Run. In their timeline, the Civil War lasted a single battle. But I digress, for we all know that in this parallel timeline Lincoln went on to become the world's first and greatest vampire hunter, single-handedly defeating Dracula, Lestat, and Count Chocula in a single bloody battle that lasted all but 42 seconds when he gunned them down with his Mini Gun. But, again, I digress, buy this book. I read physics books now. Physics books are cool.

I would definitely recommend this book to others. It's very interesting and it's guaranteed to make you feel a thousand times more like a quantum physicist than you did before. This book really kick starts your imagination and makes you dream of physics, which no one would ever think was interesting until him or her reads this book. Michio Haku makes this book an easy read, especially coming from a physicist to your everyday person. Haku writes in a way that keeps the book intriguing, even when filled with the Quantum Theory, the String Theory and the Theory of Relativity.  It's definitely not like a text book. While Physics of the Impossible has just as much, if not more, information as a text book, it remains intriguing and simple. You don't have to have a strong scientific background to be able to read this book. Anyone interested in science-fiction would appreciate this book, as it applies fiction concepts into real life. This book could also influence readers to start dreaming big. It will encourage them to not always take the unlikely for the impossible. This book is very well written and I would recommend it to all.

Popularized physics books can be boring and difficult to understand, despite the best intentions.  I think physicists often think they have successfully distilled a concept down to the level of the average joe, but in reality they have not.  I was able to follow this book basically 100% of the time, and I'm just a layman.  Plus the concept itself of evaluating common Sci-Fi technologies is fantastic.  Sometimes I wished he went into a little more detail, but that's the price you pay with these popularized books.  It might be a little hard to follow at times for someone that never reads popularized physics books (might start with Hawking's Grand Design?).  I'd also caution average readers not to overinterpret Kaku saying many of these things are possible.  While Kaku often states that the technologies are centuries away, he will state examples of already-done experiments that seem somewhat close.  A reader that isn't careful might get too rosy a view of the likelihood that we will see many of these things in our lifetimes.
Some of the other "popular" accounts of physics look like daunting text books compared to this diagram and math free book.
Very well written and explains physics in non-mathematical terms and in a most entertaining manner.

The book "Physics of the Impossible" by Michio Kako is an exciting insight into the concepts of present and future technology.  In his book, Kaku talks about "impossible" concepts, such as telepathy, teleportation, precognition, space travel, time travel, perpetual motion machines, and others.  Actually, he divides all "impossibilities" into three classes: those that are consistent with physics as we know it and actually exist in a limited sense or probably will in the near future; those that are consistent with physics as we know it, but will not be seen for centuries, if ever; and those which are actually impossible, based on our current understanding of physics.  The book is well written, very exciting, hard to put down, and relatively easy to understand.
son in law liked this book said that he learned a great deal about physics with the use of this book

In 2009's "Physics of the Impossible: A Scientific Exploration into the World of Phasers, Force Fields, Teleportation & Time Travel", Michio Kaku takes a look at some of the innovations that make science fiction what it is today & also asks the question just how plausible are these items. He divides the chapters of this book into 3 levels of plausibility things that the laws of physics allow for, things it might based upon current theory & things that aren't. His explanations are well written & concise that even the lay person can understand what he's talking about. Overall a very interesting & unique book that laid the foundation for Science Channel's "Sci-Fi Science" which he hosted for 2 seasons.

Physics of the Impossible is an interesting read. It discusses many of the cool science fictional devices we see on television and in movies. The physical plausibility of each technology is discussed, and a rough guess of how long it might take to develop (if at all). As a fellow physicist, I thought Kaku did a good job of classifying each technology in terms of plausibility. The book doesn't go into much mathematical detail, as it it a pop science book. Instead, it reasons in terms of the general principals of scientific theories, which is arguably a more useful way to think about future possibilities. The book was an easy read, and very entertaining.

Prior to purchasing this book, I watched the YouTube video entitled "Michio Kaku Physics of the Impossible  Teleportaion, Invisibility and Force Fields." He gave a fascinating lecture on cutting edge physics and the future. As someone who has always been interested in science and science fiction, I wanted to learn more, so I purchased Michio Kaku's book "The Physics of the Impossible" and was not diappointed. I give this book five stars because it sparked my interest in physics and was a fun read. He discusses all things impossible, including time travel which I enjoyed reading about. I would definately recommend this book!

This is a very cool read.  It goes into the physics of what would be needed for some of the sci-fi stuff (light sabers, transporters, phasers, etc) to actually happen in today's world or in the future.  It explains some of the more detailed physics in a way that a non-physics person can understand and stretch the mind as well.  It contains a lot of history of what has happened in physics that has made drastic changes in the various fields of science.  The book moves along fairly well, without drowning the reader in information.  Highly recommend this book to anyone who's curious about sci-fi stuff and if we can possibly make it happen.

Dr. Kaku accomplishes the seemingly impossible task of making modern physics almost make intuitive sense.  His levels of impossibility neatly partition the various concepts which have come up in science fiction into three levels of impossible, from "we'll probably have it in the next 50-100 years" to "Forget it, this idea violates pretty solid known physical principles".  He covers his topic with the same sense of excitement, humor, and wonder which make his Discovery Channel appearances so compelling and enjoyable.  Highly recommended.  I was surprised at how few science fiction concepts wound up in the third level of impossibility.

You don't need to be a physics professor to understand and follow the advanced concepts laid out in this book. If you're a fan of Jules Verne or H.G. Wells, then you'll really enjoy Dr. Kahu. His explanation of modern physics, formulations and theories are both informative and educational. It's an enjoyable read, and after a while, you won't even realize that you're being schooled on the topics of precognition, teleportation, time travel and perpetual motion machines. If you're interested in discovering more on the mysteries of the universe and modern science, you'll thoroughly enjoy reading this, and other books by the author.

I enjoyed Dr. Kaku on television and thought his book would be equally satisfying, and it was.  Einstein once said something like 'if you can't explain it, you're not as smart as you think you are' - physics should be accessible to everyone.  Through taxes, school tuitions and other means, scientists are supported - at the end of the day - by us less learned folks.  There is an obligation in the scientific community to make sure that the benefits and significance of knowledge is relayed to all of us; this gentleman does just that.  I look forward to any opportunity to listen to, see or read, what Michio has to say.

Physics of the Impossible by Dr Michio Kaku is a really cool book.  Dr Kaku goes into the various worlds of Science Fiction and pulls out fantasies that can become a reality in the near and not so near future.  He goes into depth on how physics can provide the answer to things like force shields and lightsabers.  He is a learner of English, so he has a few grammatical errors in the book. Also he focuses mostly on principles and less on how physics can make this a reality, so at times he is a little dry. But overall, if you enjoy physics and science fiction, you should enjoy this book.

I have found this book to be very interesting so far.  It describes things that have not been made yet, but which might be made in the future.  This book also shows in some cases how these things might be made.  There are some interesting new devices and ideas discussed in this book.  It also covers some newly discovered scientific phenomena, and provides a foundation to conduct further research. I really like this book, because it explains advanced concepts in a way that is easy to understand.

this book reminds me to question my purpose in life again. there are so amazing and frightening things to explore in the universe, so many questions to be asked, yet we are distracted with our small daily problems and cannot focus and ask what our purpose is in life. Universe is mighty,so breathtaking and deadly at the same time. We are just so small detail in the universe, I pity myself and people who think they are smart and better than someone else. Anyway this book is a great great getaway from our micro world and focus on other things rather than that

An interesting read, but sometimes a bit hard to follow for the layman. Although it is simplified science - there are no maths -  a lot of concepts are introduced that could do with more background. Also the book starts to get a little outdated in places. And due to a focus on astronomy and fundamental research, it lacks certain fields of science that also are interesting and about which a lot is to be said, for example, self-driving cars, synthetic meat, medical developments and technologies that could benefit the environment such as solar energy.

I enjoyed all the references to books, movies, and TV shows on the various topics but found many of the scientific explanations difficult to understand. Quantum mechanics is beyond me. Maybe if it had some illustrations? It seemed everything was about subatomic particles and math. I can understand that the math is unexplainable. I just wish there was some way to explain these concepts using everyday situations. Steven Hawkings' quote on time travel was great. "If time travel is possible, where are all the tourists from the future?"

One of the best Michio Kaku books since his "Hyperspace"...This is an essential read for anyone interested in science, science fiction, technology, and/or the future.  I have purposely made all of the above categories so broad because he covers so much and I think it it so interesting for all to read.  This is a truly important book and one that all current and budding scientists, investors (venture capitalists), and the like should read...We need to make the "impossible" possible and reading this book one can see how and then get to it...

I am a writing enthusiast, working on becoming a writing professional.  As such, I am always on the lookout for good resource material. Michio Kaku's "Physics of the Impossible" fits that description nicely.  While it is definitely not a simple "no-brainer / no gray matter necessary" read, the author nevertheless does an excellent job of taking complex topics in physics and bringing them to us in layman's terms. From a writer's perspective, this is an invaluable source of background information. I highly recommend it.

This was a fascinating book, in which seemingly preposterous or fanciful elements of fiction were dealt with in a rational manner, and the potential for the future of the given field was explored. Along the way, a lot of the frontiers of very much NON-fictional science are discussed, and the reader ends up learning a lot. This format was a great way to learn a lot and do a lot of hard thinking about fictional inventions like force fields, teleportation, faster-than-light travel, and invisibility cloaks.

I love this book!! I am a sci-fi geek from way back and I wonder how things are postulated into sci-fi books. This book explains in terms I can understand how the science is done. It wasn't until the very end of the book that I was saturated and couldn't grasp the physics. I am nowhere near a physics major. I pretty much hate high math. But he made it fun and interesting and easy to understand the concepts behind the search for ways to do what Sci-fi novels have predicted. It was exactly what I needed.

When it comes to explaining the often complicated world of physics there are very few authors that can do such an excellent job as Michio Kaku.  Dr. Kaku has the ability to easily explain complicated physics subjects such as string theory, wormholes and antimatter.  At the same time he is also able to relate these theories to everyday thinking and pop culture.  Whether you are an esteemed scientist or simply someone that is curiously fascinated by cutting edge physics and science, this is a must read.

Phenomenal book that covers the fantastic ideas like teleportation, force fields, and trips to other stars -- but does so with a rigorous analytical treatment.  Kaku finds the right balance between bringing imagination back down to earth for thoughtful analysis, while not dismissing crazy ideas.  His Class I, II, and III impossibility framework leaves room for the completely unbelievable to come to fruition.  All around a phenomenal read for those with a passion for science.

You have to hand it to the author. He takes concepts that are reserved for the power thinkers and he lays it out so the rest of us can understand how they work. A tall order but the effort is well received. Black holes, time warping, and other concepts in words that even a fifth grader can understand. Maybe a few of the readers my decide to learn more about how the universe ticks. Bravo to Michio Kaku for believing that we might buy the book, read it and then understand it.

While I'm interested in this subject matter, I don't have any formal training. Picking this book up, I was a little worried it might be less than accessible for me. I was so pleased then when I started reading and he introduced force fields in terms of Star Trek and invisibility in terms of Harry Potter. I love how well Dr. Kaku writes for a lay audience. I highly recommend this book.

I really thought this book was good.  I really liked the concept of three different types of impossibilities.  He wrote about the science of what was entailed of popular sci-fi things in a way that I could follow 99% of the time.  The only reason why I didn't give it 5 stars is that I felt that he sometimes talked about the sci-fi stuff too much when I wanted him to get on and talk about the science behind it.  However I definitely recommend.

From teleportation and time machines to force fields - are these going to be the new technologies of the future? Michio Kaku examines the latest perceptions of physical laws of the universe and the changes this understanding may bring in the near and distant future. Any who wonder why Star Trek's wonders aren't on the shelves NOW needs Physics of the Impossible: a light, involving reading for any general lending library.

This book is a summary of Michio's talks over the years.  He addresses what he believes new technologies might look like, whether science fiction might become reality, and does it all in an easily understandable way.  I never felt like he was talking down to me in the process, but that I was sharing in his contagious excitement for his field of work.  A must read for those interested in physics, sciences, etc as a major.

I never liked science in school but this book was a fun read. Some of the concepts are dense and there is a lot of history but the author has a talent for breaking it down so it's easy to understand. He drew on contemporary and easy to fathom examples that helped with this too. His classification of the technologies into three categories was also very interesting and helped to distinguish what was really within grasp.

Although this book touchs on the possibilities and impossibilities of the things written in fiction movies and books, it also gives a lot of real information. If you like physics or just want to understand the world and it's possibilities, this is a great book. I don't normally read books cover to cover, I usually skip around, picking and choosing chapters. This is the first book I read completely in over 10 years.

What this book ultimately tells us is this: The more we know about the inner workings of the Universe, the more there is to know in unequal proportions. If you enjoy physics at all, or are the least bit curious about what mysteries the greatest minds are spending their time unraveling, then this is the book for you. It was written in 2009, it seems, and will hopefully have revisions every decade or so.

Physics of the Impossible is a very interesting book-Not only does it tell us the physics behind sci-fi staples, it also tells us how impossible, "magic" technologies like invisibility, are possible. "Impossibilities" are divided into 3 classes-each telling us how soon each "impossibility" will be commonplace, amazingly, most technologies are class I; possible within a century. I highly recommend it.

this book is engaging, from the moment i started reading it i could not stop until i finished. being a fan of science fiction i thoroughly enjoyed reading prof. Kaku's explanations for how the things we once thought of as only being the topic of science fiction are actually possible and some already exist! "Physics of the impossible" is a fantastic literary journey into the realm of possibilities.
I read Michio Kaku like some folks read the bible.

Easy to read and understand, while opening your mind to the reality that things will change and evolve, making s ience fiction, or dreams into reality. The ability of the human psyche is valuable to sustain our lives and the planet.... Perhaps not as we know it, but improved and sustainable. Other good thoughts: no long airport waits, teleport yourself when you are ready!

I firmly believe that when one reaches age 50 or so your brain is at maximum capacity.  After 50, when you learn something new, or grasp a new concept something else must leave your mind to make room. You do not get to choose what leaves. I absolutely loved this book. After reading it from cover to cover I can no longer find my keys or remember my grandchildren s names.

This book is uplifting for any scientist that truly believes that he or she can change the world one day.  Kaku describes how teleportation and other concepts might actually be developed.  Hopefully one of his readers is already hard at work finding the solution.  After reading this book, it had me thinking for days.  If only I had a budget the size of NASA's.

By reading this, one will be amazed that some of the most incredible sci-fi ideas are being developed right now in our time. You will understand the craziness in your favorite movies, books, and shows in a new way and think about how super science may actually come about. Science and fiction our not just married in the movies, they are one in the real world.

The style in which it is written, each chapter addressing a different topic vs. novel-like, adds to it attractiveness. I can pick it up and just get lost in the concepts it presents to me and the physics, while well beyond my education, are not a road block.

Interesting reading, rich in ideas, many of them ... impossible. A clear and revelatory enumeration of questions for which we don't have an answer yet. Personally I would of preferred a bit more science and less fiction. Trying to keep partisan sci fi preferences aside I think the multiple references to movies diminish a bit the book substance.

It is a good book for those looking forward for an introduction on some very interesting forward looking physics developments. I found it to be too high level though, but this is just related to my expectation. The book itself, if you have a little different expectation that I had is good, and is written in easy to grasp language/approach.

This is another amazing read from the prolific Michio Kaku. He is an inspiration to all aspiring scientists, researchers and explorers! Read at your own peril as you will not view 'impossible' as so impossible after finishing this treaty to human ingenuity and imagination. It may prove to mind expanding for the cynical or pessimistic!

Whoa, just when you thought you had your mind accepting the Big Bang, Kaku jump-starts your imagination with some of the things that are not only possible, but probable.  This guy is great at making un "good 'ol boys" understand the concepts of advanced physics.  Read him and learn the possible of the impossible.

This book is easy to read for the non scientist. I must say that Michio Kaku is a little more optimistic than he used to be since the last time I emailed him in the early 90's. I really enjoyed the concepts of this book and it has a similar feel as The Science of Star Trek. If your are a big scifi fan, you'll love this.

Michio Kaku takes the reader through a series of fascinating possibilities that most of us thought were only real on Star Trek. But he shows how theoretically, many different unbelievable things in the physical realm, could actually turn out to be true.  He shows how some have already been proven, or already happened.

EXCELLENT BOOK! If you are not a sci-fi fan you might not like some of the comparisons, but explaining things like force fields and how they could someday really happen and even giving examples of real experiments with each thing in labs is AMAZING. Trust me, even if you know nothing of math you will understand this!

I bought this book for my 14-year-old son, after listening to it myself on Audible, and he loved it.  If you or your teenager enjoys science fiction and/or real science, this is an excellent overview of what the future has in store for us -- so long as we as a society continue to value research and scientific truth.

Accessible and fascinating! I loved the quotes and examples used throughout the book! The ideas are beautifully presented, clear and tangible despite the profound subject nature! As a bit of a nerd, I loved the references throughout, yet appreciated that they never distracted from nor overwhelmed the themes.

Dr Kaku  clearly distinguishes what we knew then, know now,  might know in the future, and may never know. He draws  on history and sci fi to demonstrate progress and potential. Very helpful for one who studied Physics in the middle of the last century, but alas, I still couldn't quite master it all.

Kaku has a fantastic writing style. He writes simply enough to not lose the everyday reader, while still being interesting to someone with a background in physics.  This book talks about the feasibility of everyone's favorite scifi gadgets.  A fantastic book, and one I can't wait to reread.

A fun and informative read. I am fairly well acquainted with all the topics in the book yet the author was still able to hold my interest throughout the entire work. Easily understood explanations along with a conversational writing style makes this an easy book to recommend.

This is a great book. Try to get your hands on everything that Dr.Kaku writes. You will not be disappointed. I gave the book to a few friends that have no science background. At first they were not so sure about it. After the first few chapters, they couldn't put it down.

The promulgation of new ideas with a solid foundation is really a thrill.  great to pick up and read a little, then think about it while you do the mundane tasks that keep food on the table and a roof over your head, and then read a little more.  Some many great ideas!

Michio crafts a wonderful read of Science fiction and the reality of their past, present, and future. Entertaining, informative, and easily worth a second and third read. This book should be a requirement for every student planning on studying the sciences.

This is a great book for anyone interested in topics such as time travel, parallel universes etc. who also doesn't happen to understand all of the math behind the physics. Michio Kaku is able to make the average person understand these complex ideas.

If you are a sci-fi and science geek (like me) you will find this very interesting.  Kaku blends the reality of our world with the possibilities promised by sci-fi... and gives us wonder by promising what we might otherwise feel is impossible.

This is an amazing book for those that love physics and know it, as well as those that don't really know what physical laws make our planet/world what it is. It is a great read! Anyone can pick up this book and appreciate physics. Awesome!

I've always enjoyed listening to Prof Kaku on Coast to Coast with Art Bell but had never read his books. This is the first I got and was not disappointed! Complicated subjects but presented in an easy-to-understand manner. Loved the book!

Liked the book quite much, though the editing does leave room for improvement. Things are repeated funnily and there are long paragraphs in parentheses that clearly would not need them, they are so essential to the preceding text.

I have been curious of other books by this author.  I hope this is a good second choice.  I like the way he makes concepts of physics and science in general accessible to those of us with limited background in said fields.

I don't know anything about physics, so I found this book to be quite fascinating.  This is not a book that can be read quickly.  There is a lot of scientific information that needs to be understood.  Kaku provides a historical background for each concept, which I appreciated.  The chapter on psychokinesis is very interesting.  Psychokinesis is the ability to use the mind to move or manipulate things.  I did not know that psychokinesis is used in the medical field for people who are paralyzed.  The chapter on antimatter is a new concept for me.  I had to read this chapter twice to fully understand it.  I did not know that antimatter could be used as fuel to launch rockets in the future.  I also enjoyed reading the chapter about the real possiblity that invisibility could become a reality as scientists learn more about how to bend light.  Flying cars could also become a reality in the future, as scientific knowledge of magnetic fields progresses.  Kaku talks briefly about string theory as the theory to explain everything.  There is not too much information on this concept, but it sounds interesting to me.  The chapter on time travel is very interesting but rather short.  Physics of the Impossible is a very educational and informative book.

Very satisfied with the cost of this book for how good it is.  It's a book that takes you out of the realm of normal though, and intrigues you to open your mind!  Highly recommended for anyone with an open mind!

Gave a sense of reality to the scientific fictions that we read or see as movies.The relevance of many mathematical theories in our life is brought home nicely.Science students ,I am sure,will appreciate it.
Great book.  For the most part it was understandable and enjoyable.  There still were some places that I was lost but considering the topic I was happy.
Excellent Book! If you're into science like me this book is what you need to read. It was awesome and I couldn't put it down.Thanks for writing it Mr Kaku, I will look into reading your other books!
Some interesting stuff in this book yet, in my opinion, it's written with the young teen in mind. Nothing wrong with that; anything that helps get our kids hooked on science I'm all for!
blew my mind grapes. I love this book because it focuses on things that are possible, will be possible, and are just not possible. It also explains why these things are the way they are.
A uniquely mindblowing, fascinating, entertaining experience that will change how you view the cosmos and the future of mankind. Easily the greatest work of literature I have ever read.
Wonderful book--it gives the probability of future science becoming reality and when. Quite enjoyable for the general public, you don't have to be a science nerd to read and enjoy it.
If you love science and thinking about the future you would definitely enjoy this book. I haven't learned this much since high school, and even then I don't think I learned that much.
I've just started reading this book and it's extremely fascinating and easy-to-understand.It's the best book if you wanna know more about the edge of physics and what lies beyond.
This book is highly interesting, and entertaining. If your a sci-fi nerd, then this book is for you. Written clearly and easy to understand (with plenty of Star Trek references).
i have always had an interest in physics, but without formal training in the math of it I have had a grasp at it at best. but it seams to have helped wrap my mind around it.....
I have become very fascinated with the writing's of Professor Kaku. This book lets you imagination soar with possibilities for the future. A very good read for all  ages!
Can't say I always understand the terminology but find the glimpses of the future we'll never live to see fascinating. Maybe I'll get to enjoy some of them in my next life!
Great book,I only bought the book after highly recommended by one of my best friends in JORDAN and never knew of this author,now will get his other books.well done Amazon
It processed really fast, it got here really fast. If I want any kind of product I always check Amazon first, because they always seem to have it and it's usually cheaper
As with the rest of the Kaku books and videos this is perfect non math major work.  I love reading about quantum physics and theory of everything stuff so this was a joy.
I purchased 2 of these, one for my boyfriend and one for me, we enjoy reading this interesting and exciting book together.  Thank you Michio, the next great Carl Sagan!
Easy to understand; Quantum Physics discussions were at the right level to support the understanding of the subject matter. Good book for Techies, or just plain people
Dr.Kaku has writtten an easily  understandable book on questions that  occur to "everyone"  at times.  His explanations of major questions are concise and friendly.
Very well written and easy to understand for the average reader.  An incredible amount of insight into topics that  previously seemed too difficult to understand.
Easily my favorite book of his. It's great for getting an introduction to various "impossible" technologies, though don't expect an in-depth explanation.
An excellent view of the possible future use of physicsIt is very interesting to see how physics could be applied to most unespected situatios of read life.
Wow!  Professor Kaku invites inviting one's interest and has a way of communicating the possibilities of the future that the ordinary person can understand.
I was hoping this book would be something like stephen hawking's "the grand design". This is a book made to sell, no real valuable information here
great view of science of potential to implausible....i dont believe the impossible part..we just dont know how doesn't make it impossible. so say daedalus
Nicely done, thorough, consistent. Enjoyed the stories and conjectures. Enjoyed reading it. Followed all current thinking I and projections on the topic
I found this a great read not only for the for its purpose but it also explains many complex theories of physics that the average reader can understand.
Very entertaining read. Kaku writes in a very fluid and happy style, energetic and invigorating for anybody that likes deep science or science fiction.
I really enjoyed the book it's amazing theories and interesting info is great it as addresses many things I have always wondered as bout I loved it !!!
very useful and interesting reading I like it.many things I thought about before take its  right place.I thank author for this book.Slava from Russia
Except for the chapter on UFOs, which I strongly sugest you skip, this is an incredible book that I recommend to anyone with an inquisitive mind.
This book presents how physics will make certain technological advances possible and Kaku makes it exciting reading as it is with all his books.
extremely interesting, although i feel like faster than light should be in class III, since relativity states it to be the fastet speed possible
Michio continues the tradition of excellent written, advanced but enjoyable, books. Must have for M.K. readers and any other inquisitive person.
The subject was very interesting even for a layperson like me.  Some of the material was over my head but I enjoyed reading the book anyway.
Great book, Michio has a great way of explaining things so you can understand what he's talking about. Think I'll go do some time traveling.
Although there are difficult words that I don't understand, I still love this book very much. Recommend to who loves physic and cosmology.
This book is great for those great interested in physics, in fact, it's one of the best books that I have read! Keep it up Michio Kaku!!
Dr.Kaku has an extremely interesting way to face science fiction gadgets and approach them as a very intelligent and open minded person.
I've been a fan of Mr. Kaku's for years now.  The book is a good read. When I finish this one, I will read his Parallel Universes".
This is a great book, if you like Dr Kaku's tv show you'll enjoy this book although there's some duplication from the show to the book.
Kaku has a wonderful way of writing for the layperson.  He covered some very esoteric physics and I believe I actually understood him.
Great book for the price. Every time I read it I feel smarter. Brings the probality of Science Fiction into Science Fact Probability.
Enjoyed this book very much. It's clear and very well written. Michio Kaku makes the impossible as easy as possible to understand.
I Love this book. Being a fan of sci-fi and a science teacher, I love making the connections between fantasies and possibilities.
This is the second book I have read by Michio Kaku.  He is a very good writer and does a good job explaining physics concepts.
Wonderful, thought-provoking book by an Einsteinian physicist who manages to make such a subject read like an exciting novel!
My daughter loves Michio Kaku and finds realism in his prophecy of the future. Always looking for more good books like this!
Michio Kaku is the Carl Sagan of the 21st century. Can't say any more.  He has a radio show on Saturday afternoon/evenings.
Examines the real-world physics behind teleportation, shields, phasers, warp drive, lightspeed, and alternate universes.
Excellent reading material, very easy to read and understand... I'm just starting to read it, so far i'm very pleased...
MICHIO KAKU IS NOT ONLY GREAT SCIENTIST BUT ALSO GREAT WRITER ON SCIENTIFIC SUBJECTS. HIS TV PROGRAMS ARE ALSO WONDERFUL
I love Michio Kaku's work.  He has a gift for explaining the difficult to understand in easy to understand language.
I don't understand why he ruled out precognition.  He said it violated causality, but I can't see the connection.
There is much to say about this book.  However, I think he went beyond his expertise in writing about the brain.
I felt the subject matter was more "fantasy thinking" than hard science.  It just wasn't my cup of tea.
Required for a class, it was in great shape with no dog flaps on any of the pages. It looked just like new!
Interesting to consider the gap between the physics of science fiction and the physics we learn in school.
I enjoyed reading Physics of the Impossible, although much of the physics Michio Kaku cites is beyond me!
Bought for my son of 15yrs and he loved it-he has considered buying more from this author at a later date
One of the best popular science books regarding past, present, and most of all, future technologies.
Gave this to my husband as a gift. He loves science, and has enjoyed all of the Michio Kaku books.
My first kindle ebook. Only a couple of bucks and one of the best reads I've had in a long time.
Chapters vary in size, but most of the info and narrative is bite-sized so it is a joy to read.
This author seems to know my questions and he poses them and answers them.  Terrific read.
This is a book one can not stop reading.  Michio Kaku can make the impossible readable!
Michio Kaku is a phenomenal writer.  Makes physics easier to understand for the layman.

Dr. Kaku presents another outstanding book to expand our minds to endless possibilities. Why limit ourselves when we need, more than ever, to think out of the box, and ask the big "what if" questions. In my own writing, vis-i-vis, The Ninth Cube, I have tried to answer these questions, alot of them inspired from the work of Dr. Kaku. I throughly enjoyed this book and would recommend it to anyone. Great job, Michio!
Written at the perfect level for my duaghter's research paper.
Such a great book for sci-fi nerds questioning the impossible.
it is alright. The explanations are ok. Philosophy is median.
Clearly explained and pretty good written in a simple way
excelent for young people whohave an interest in science
Very good for anyone who loves both Sci-fi and physics.

Author.Name: Romulo P. Giorgi Jr.
Author.Location: Brazil, Rio Gande do Sul, Porto Alegre..

ReviewList.Text: Excellent ...i will buy more of these books by Kaku...
Very well written for the non-physicist. Entertaining.
Intelligently written and facinating work and writer.

This book is a great read.  Michio lays out topics of science fiction one by one, and explains how they will become (or are becoming) science fact.  This book is packed with information and interesting speculation into the world of theoretical physics.

I have been a student of the sciences, philosophy, theology and many other "ologies" for the last 40 years. This book ties many elements together and really allows the imagination to grasp where we could be headed.
This was a fantastic book, I own it in hard cover.  I have nothing bad to say about it, except that despite the cover art, Doctor Who isin't mentioned once in the entire text.
Interesting to read by Dr. Kaku.
this book is awesome, this will open your mind. I'm not done reading it yet but I have a problem of putting it down. Its a got to read book.
Entertaining, easy reading, serious but delivered easily. A must for the science lover with an open mind.
Very entertaining.
An excellent book
I got it on time
Good Product .
A little dated
fascinating!
fascinating

Author.Name: Dr. Joseph S. Maresca
Author.Location: CPA,CISA, Published Author in Bronxville, New York USA

ReviewList.Text: I read most of this book from a copy from my local library for some research I am doing. I found it so informative and easy to understand, even though I do not have a background in physics, that I bought this plus two other books by the same author. I find it very interesting, and it puts into perspective what "science fiction" feats may be possible, probably or are too way out there to be real.
Great book
Good read!
good stuff
A gift.
Great!

The great Michio Kaku. The second Einstein. Me makes physics understandable easily. He explains the laws and all his ideas in a way that even a 10 year-old could understands. A recommended read. Very recommended to Trekkies!

Would like to see a revision with some of the latest research and discoveries included. Still, this is an outstanding book that explains many popular beliefs and ideas, and why they may or probably will never work.

Michio's popular books are popcorn. Looking back on it though, I never heard him mention the (tech) singularity so I rate this lower that what I would if I were on,y to rate it on "just being a fun read"

Overall, I enjoyed this book. Some topics were well presented and educational. However, some of the book was superficial, reflecting the author's lack of knowledge/experience regarding the particular subjects.
Understandable explanation of when science "fiction" becomes reality on several of the more popular devices, e.g., death rays, invisibility, transporting, telekinesis, etc.  Fun and factual!
This book was very interesting and easy to read. I still may have a little trouble with string theory but I understood the rest and it has a lot of good history of all the theory.
My daughter loved the book.  Seems the picture on the cover has images from "Dr. Who", one of her favorite programs.  Just the book to interest and challenge the mind.
An informative book that got 3stars from me for that information, but it is dull and slow. A good read for a young person contemplating a possible career in physics.

Somewhat interesting for the average reader. However, truly educated guesswork, and not typical of Michio Kaku's ability of explaining difficult subject matter. I was disappointed in his many "Star Trek" examples, and it seems obvious this book was written for some unimportant spur of the moment personal itch. Although Mr. Kaku is a favorite author of mine, I really can't recommend this book.

Author.Name: Bill Oterson
Author.Location: About 60 miles, or so, east of Manhattan.

ReviewList.Text: good
This new release by Michio Kaku has me thinking about subjects in his book that I have not known of before. It opens up a new world of subjects, many I knew about, many I didn't. Thought provoking.
Not  an easy read. You would need to re-read several times to "get it". I think you need some background.
No problems whatsoever with the download, and it's great reading material for those who are a fan of Dr. Kaku!
Great topics, great writing and easy to follow.  I'd recommend it for anyone interested in future technology.
I get more than I expected. It's very good for me. I recommend the products in 100% for all that can get it.
I have never read a book about physics so I didn't know what to expect! I feel I got a bit of an education and had a lot of fun reading it. Thanks
this book is very interesting..in a few years we will thank kaku for formulating the 'impossible'
Fascinating - A step out of the expance of the cosmos and deep into our minds.

Michio Kaku really makes astronomy and physics fun and makes physics easy to understand. An easy read that covers pretty much all astronomy topics that I had searched for in a book, I.E.: Time travel, UFO's, Parallel universes and much more. Can't wait to get some of his other works.

I read another book by Michio Kaku (Hyperspace) years ago and am still re-reading it, it is so entertaining and fascinating.  Truth be told, I've always been fascinated with quantum theory and all the quirks (no pun intended) associated with it.  This books is even better than Hyperspace because it delves into many various concepts and then the author uses current technology and understanding (as well as his hypothecating about future technologies) to determine whether the concept is ever going to be possible.  For example, he discusses the Death Star (a la Star Wars) and concludes that eventually (hundreds of thousands or even a million years from now), technology may exist that can reproduce the planet-destroying capability of such a thing.  His writing is entertaining and though some of the concepts are frankly not understandable for the average person (including me), it's nonetheless still enjoyable to read it.  I've read some chapters multiple times.

Wanna know what the future holds?  Put down that crystal ball and pick up a copy of "Impossible Physics"!  The author goes through all of coolest sci-fi technologies and explains exactly where we are on developing them and what we need to do before they will become possible.  For example, we've made amazing advances toward invisibilty since 2006 and within a decade or two Harry Potter's cloak won't be very impressive anymore.  I don't have a science background, but luckily the book explains complex theories in a way that is delightfully accessible to anyone with an understanding of 8th grade science.

This book truly makes physics fun. I'm anxious to share it with my son as he gets a little older, as I feel it will help inspire him to "think big" and dream of what's possible. Michio Kaku uses real science to explain the ideas and fantasies of science fiction in an intriguing and easy to understand way. The book is an excellent introduction to quantum physics for the layperson, although I would imagine it's too simple to be a reference for physicists. I thoroughly enjoyed the book and found it to be a fast read.

I found this to be an interesting read, but I was disappointed to find many errors - not necessarily in content, but in wording and sentence structure. For example, "Newtons's laws are so all-embracing that if you know the location and position of all the molecules in the universe..." Obviously, he meant location and velocity. The reader will usually know what was meant, but I would hope the author would have the book proof-read before any future printings.
monotonous
Great one

I would put this on the must read list for anyone who's interested in science, technology, and sci fi. It looks at those things we see in movies and on TV and gives an honest, straightforward approach to these questions and does so in plain English. Get it, read it, love it.

I heard Kaku on the radio,years ago,and found him captivating.Physics of the Impossible is beguiling because of its subjects,such as Teleportation and Time Travel.This is far more interesting and exciting than Science Fiction.Maybe I can become invisible at will!
As an engineer and a lover of physics, this book is awe-inspiring and just an overall great read. I recommend it to anyone that has any interest in science fiction or even just science fact.
A brilliant insight to the possible, and what seems impossible, of future technologies. A must read for both novice and technical readers of physics literature.
This Book is a great begginer guide into the sate of the human race now and what we can achieve in the future.

This was my first Kaku book to read and I was dissapointed to find it so dull.  I have seen and heard Dr. Kaku on various TV and radio programs and was expecting the same energy from his book.  What I found was after the initial few sentences on the subject(death stars, time travel, etc.) the focus shifted away from the fantastic to the mundane and ended up reading like a technical manual.  The difference between 'why it's impossible' to 'how it could be possible' is subtle, but it makes the difference between dull and entertaining.  I did find the chapter on robots and artificial intelligence fascinating.  Unfortunately, it was the only engrossing chapter in the book and I was relieved when I finally finished it.

This book is great. Michiu has a way of explaining extremely technical processes in simple, easy to understand ways. This book really opens your eyes to the future and present of technology. I highly recommend this book for any techy.

An excellent tome that amply compliments its sister works, "Happy Endings" and "I Hate Your Guts" by renowned philosopher and pop cultural guru Jim Norton.  A finer treatment of the use and construction of Flux Capacitors cannot be found anywhere in the literary universe.
Kaku takes you to the edge of the universe in ways that are hard to even think about!
This was a gift to my husband, according to him he really did enjoy it
This is the best book I have ever read.  I could not put it down.

although i have not finished reading the book yet. it is still entertaining. kaku presents fantasistic ideas and breaks then down scientifically to show how they would work in reality. i will admit that the subject matter is not for everyone but i enjoy it.
I haven't had the time to read more then a few pages, but what I have read is very intresting, I'm beginning to think theirs a wormhole somewhere in my backyard now. I WISH!

As true lover or real science, I am disappointed the Mr Kaku has abandoned his senses and instead writes junk to make himself popular. while his books are selling, he is not providing real science to the the public which I find very lacking in knowledge of science.
I have high hope for this book, but it is not good enough, too few of case studies and too many theories.

I have read two of his books and am convinced he has no writing skills and his popular science books are just science fiction. There is no attempt to explain hard science principles in layman. The books are just chatter and after two chapters I am putting all his books in the "white elephant christmas party" gift wraps of our department!

The book is well-written, but there is nothing new here that hasn't already been published and explained elsewhere.  Star Trek stuff like phasers, transporters and forcefields are included -- and I've seen more detailed presentations in other books.  He approaches time travel with a less than skeptical eye.  Included are invisibility and matter-antimatter reactions as well as non-scientific topics like telekinesis and precognition.  Again, nothing new, all been done before, although Kaku did have a good section on parallel universes versus multiverses.  It took me a half hour to go through the whole book, admittedly skimming since I didn't find much that was new or unique.  I will mention that Kaku thinks that precognition is impossible, but I have a feeling, um, let's see, yes -- that this book will appeal to teenagers with an interest in science who have not already read all the other books of its kind already on the market or on the library shelves.

The possible physics is delightful, insightful and entertaining. Unfortunately physics, especially quantum physics has the need to understand consciousness (not just for the collapse of the wave function). The author is arrogant and ignorant on the subject of consciousness, and assumes that consciousness can be explained by physics. In this he has it backwards. Consciousness, or conscious Bbeing is the fundamental reality. At no time is there any attempt to define consciousness (which I define as awareness and will which is force). Physics explains the color blue (for example) as an electromagnetic wave of such and such a frequency - which in no way is an explanation for the conscious experience of "blue". Nevertheless, the book is worth reading.
But the kindle version was 20+% more expensive than the hard copy. Foolish pricing and I will not reward such stupidity.

It is difficult to realize that a book about parallel universes, pyschic phenomenon, faster than the light travel, etc., could be humdrum boring - but this book proves it is possible to write a boring book about such topics.  This was a superficial, half-hearted review of these topics written perhaps for the reader with absolutely no science knowledge.  Very disappointing.
The book arrived like new. It is a very interesting book for those who like general physics and some of the stories behind the old and new developments. I highly recommend it

I can't believe all the rave reviews of this book, which encouraged me to buy it.  How disappointing it turned out to be.  To me, it is a tired rehash of ground that Kaku and others have covered thoroughly before, and his knowledge of science fiction is nowhere near as great as he thinks it is.  Time he retired.

Author.Name: Nick Gleiter
Author.Location: San Francisco, CA, USA, Earth, Sol, Milky Way, Virgo Cluster

ReviewList.Text: I would love to say that I enjoyed this book immensely; however, since I never received it, I have nothing to go on.  I tried several times to contact the shipper privately, but I never received a response there, either, and I still don't have the book.  Based on my experience, I'd say to stay away from this bookseller if at all possible, as you never know what you might get from them -- or not.
